documents.document: @juter @andybudd @jasonmesut @evalottchen I’m now asking myself whenever I see a model: - what is it accurately representating - what is it misrepresenting or fully omitting something, - Should I ignore what the model ignores?

@juter @jasonmesut @evalottchen @andybudd That realisation changed my outlook a lot. I used that illustration on a slide to explain it this morning: we know the Earth is a globe but we need a flat map so here’s what we use despite it massively distorting area near the poles. https://t.co/n4hqszLBnm
Tesco direct to close. https://t.co/hNhHWH8w3J Never made any sense for them to have two completely separate websites. Sooner or later reality wins. /cc @dcjarvis

Protip: you can use keyboard events while drag and dropping files. Ie drag files to your Mac slack app, don’t release click but press CMD+K type in the name of the person/channel you want to post to, then release mouse click.
@PhilipMorton True but was always part on the product story. Also thinking watch + purposeful decision of what notifications you allow there are the most efficient way to use your phone less.
… et pour les francophones plus ou moins anglophobes, noter que l’app est intégralement traduite en français.

Had another very mind feeding session at @LibStructLDN . Very new and profound way to rethink what “meetings” can be. Recommended to anyone in UX service design, or any leadership really.

@andybudd I’m not sure Clearleft would have outlasted many other agencies as it did without the conferences org/speaking/books you and team do... Good luck for this UX LDN, all my teammates will attend it, looking froward to hear the impact on them :)

So @outline has a great article on how @facebook is tracking you, likely without you realising, on 8.4 Million sites. To read it, you just need to approve 95(!) cookies, only 6 they themselves describe as necessary. https://t.co/pjTnqJmQqM The state of the web today :/ https://t.co/eZ9qyvVlI9

@sparrk My gut feel is most country will be tempted to avoid fights with megacorps that could outgun them lawyer wise, will also avoid small corps as harsh to pick on little guys who can’t do much damage. So mostly mid size corps as targets…

@sparrk My impression also (also did some GDPR for $newjob). But what is the enforcement process? I think it’s country based, but surely makes no sense for every country to investigate the same international corps? I fear the ICO legal department might be woefully undersized…

@dawuss Yes. But this is like the absolute most basic they can do, the most obvious and not that powerful. Of course they can do much more…

@lmjabreu People don’t yet realise how deeply your privacy is breeched when you give access to your banking. Location of payment, strong hints of medical history, credit behaviour. Oh, and full list of where you buy (often saying what you buy).
@lmjabreu It is then to the local enforcement agency to access that claim, and I believe they can rule an infraction if they deem it so.

Well deserved. Another great example of the impact fantastic storytelling can have. It didn’t tell anything new about plastic, but created the visceral, emotional response that is leading to action. https://t.co/bYofuyYFuR

@dawuss That’s not exactly hard to do TBH, when users give you: - location tracking either by visit or in each photo shared (=understand holidays patterns) - home address - employer and job title - education history - vast amount of self written text

@andybudd Hum. What was the “testing” then? Usability testing isn’t a method that will give you an exhaustive list… it works by flagging larger issues, just because something doesn’t show in x test doesn’t mean it isn’t an issue. (As I’m sure you know)
@andybudd What is a “false” usability issue? How are the “real” issues determined then? 🤔🤨

@sparrk Another answer: Everybody with 10-15 year experience in UX now started in another career simply because the field wasn’t there. So being from “outside” is currently the norm, not the exception.
